contents.context:
World leaders and organizations have promised to stump up more than 8 billion U.S. dollars to develop a vaccine and treatments for COVID-19.
The pledges were made Monday by 30 different countries in a video conference hosted by the European Union.
It was organized by the European Union and other countries including Britain, Norway and Saudi Arabia, Canada and Japan.
The United States did not choose to contribute, saying it's already pouring billions of dollars into its own research.
UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres said he is glad to be taking part in the project along with the World Health Organization.


"These new tools can help us to fully control the pandemic and must be treated as global public goods available and affordable for all. This is the only path to a world free of COVID-19. But this will require the most massive public health effort in history."

The Director General of the WHO, Dr. Tedros, welcomed the funds but said the results should be equally distributed.


"The ultimate measure of success will not be how fast we can develop tools. It will be how equally we can distribute them. None of us can accept a world in which some people are protected while others remain exposed."

He also said that this is an opportunity not only to defeat a common enemy but to forge a common future.
Eum Ji-young Arirang News.
Reporter : jy_rachel@arirang.com
contents.headline:
World leaders pledge US$ 8 bil. to develop vaccine, treatments for COVID-19
Updated: 2020-05-05 12:55:18 KST

contents.context:
In some countries the coronavirus pandemic is only getting worse.
Russia has seen more than 10-thousand cases for two days in a row now as the total number of cases there approaches 150-thousand.
The country last week extended its period of isolation until May 11th, with President Putin saying the worst is yet to come.
In the United States, the New York Times says it's obtained an internal projection from the White House saying that there could be 3-thousand coronavirus deaths per day by the first of June.
Right now the U.S. has about 1.1 million cases as some states start to reopen their economies.
And in Europe, Spain and Italy, two of the hardest hit countries, are reopening quickly now.
Those two have seen the number of deaths fall to 160 or 170 a day, the lowest since early to mid-March.
In Britain, officials say the outbreak has peaked.
Reporter : devin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
New COVID-19 hotspot Russia reporting 10,000 cases a day
Updated: 2020-05-05 12:54:18 KST

contents.context:
The number of global COVID-19 cases now surpassed three-and-a-half million.
The number of deaths worldwide is over 247-thousand.
Infections in Russia rose by a record daily amount on Sunday, with over 10-thousand 6-hundred new cases, with more than half in Moscow.
However, much of Europe is preparing to ease lockdown measures as the spread seems to have slowed.
Italy once deemed the world's hotspot, reported Sunday its lowest daily death toll since the first day of its lockdown.
Italy's death toll stands at almost 29-thousand, with at least 210-thousand infections.
Germany will continue easing of lockdown measures this week, while France will partially lift its lockdown on May 11th.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Europe slowly easing COVID-19 lockdowns as spread slows; Russia records highest daily confirmed cases
Updated: 2020-05-04 10:19:50 KST

contents.context:
U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo says there's "enormous evidence" the COVID-19 pandemic originated in a lab in Wuhan,. echoing remarks made last week by President Trump.
Speaking to ABC's "This Week" on Sunday, Pompeo said it's not the first time that the "world has been exposed to viruses as a result of failures in a Chinese lab", adding that China has had its "history of running substandard" labs.
Despite being highly critical of China's handling of the matter, Pompeo declined to comment on whether he believes the virus was released intentionally.
Last Thursday, President Trump claimed he had seen evidence the virus had originated in a Chinese lab.
Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com
contents.headline:
'Enormous evidence' COVID-19 originated in Wuhan lab: Pompeo
Updated: 2020-05-04 05:57:45 KST

contents.context:
It appears B-1B Lancers returned to the Indo-Pacific region early this month for bomber task force operations out of Anderson Air Base in Guam.
Military sources say four bombers and some 200 airmen from an air base in Texas were deployed to support Pacific Air Forces' training efforts with U.S. allies and carry out strategic deterrence missions to strengthen the rules-based international order in the region.
It's the first time B-1s have been deployed to the region since 2017.
The source added the South Korean military was notified prior to deployment.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
U.S. sends 4 B-1B Lancers to Indo-Pacific region to reinforce strategic deterrence missions: Source
Updated: 2020-05-04 05:56:45 KST

contents.context:
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has granted emergency use authorization of the experimental antiviral drug remdesivir for treating hospitalized COVID-19 patients on Friday.
The FDA decision greatly waives formal safety standards, only requiring the drug's potential benefits to be greater than the risks.

The approval came after the drug produced by Gilead Sciences was shown to be effective in treating the coronavirus.
In a study conducted on more than one-thousand patients, the drug appeared to have shortened the recovery time by 31%, which is around 4 days on average.
With the emergency authorization, remdesivir will be allowed for COVID-19 patients or those suspected to be infectedwhose condition is considered "severe."
President Donald Trump announced the decision on Friday alongside the CEO of Gilead Sciences, Daniel O'Day.


"I'm pleased to announce that Gilead now has an EUA from the FDA for RemdsevirAnd it's something, I spoke with Dr. Kahn, Dr. Fauci. I spoke with Deborah about it and it's really a very promising situation."

Daniel O'Day added that the company is donating a significant amount of the drug to help people in need.


"And we want to make sure nothing gets in the way of these patients getting the medicine. So, we made a decision to donate about 1.5 million vials of Remdesivir."

Following the news, an official for South Korea's Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said the center is currently discussing with related authories and departments the drug's clinical test results as well as reviewing preferential treatment for import in case it is necessary.
KIM Sung-min, Arirang News
Reporter : smkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
FDA grants emergency use of remdesivir for COVID-19
Updated: 2020-05-03 09:09:40 KST

contents.context:
The World Health Organization's COVID-19 Emergency Committee urged the organization to give appropriate travel guidelines.
The committee said on Friday strategic guidance was necessary to gradually allow travel again, and that appropriate protection should be provided in case physical distancing is hard to be implemented.
The committee also advised the WHO to continue cooperation with partners in enabling essential travel such as for humanitarian relief and cargo operations.
The Director-General of the WHO also declared Friday that the COVID-19 outbreak still continues to form a public health emergency of international concern.
Reporter : smkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
COVID-19 Emergency Committee urges WHO to give appropriate travel guidance
Updated: 2020-05-02 12:12:17 KST

contents.context:
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has given a green light to the most promising treatment so far to tackle COVID-19.
The FDA authorized the emergency use of experimental antiviral drug Remdesivir on Friday.
The drug maker Gilead Sciences said that it's donating 1.5 million vials of the drug and will work with the federal government to help patients in need.
The news comes days after preliminary results from a study showed that the drug could help patients recover faster.
The American drug company had originally developed Remdesivir to treat Ebola.
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
FDA authorizes emergency use of Remdesivir to treat COVID-19 patients
Updated: 2020-05-02 11:50:51 KST

contents.context:
The head of the United Nations has called South Korea a "remarkable example" of containing and recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic.
Pointing to how South Korea saw no new confirmed cases on Thursday, UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said at a news conference that Seoul has been "extremely successful" in addressing the pandemic.
He added that South Korea plans to tackle climate change during the recovery, with what he called "a very ambitious green deal" that includes a ban on new coal-fired plants and a reduction in emissions from existing coal-fired plants.
Guterres stressed that he hopes South Korea's example will be followed by other countries around the world.
South Korea saw a peak of almost 1,000 cases a day between late February and early March.
But thanks to preemptive testing and social distancing, the caseload was recently greatly reduced.
Seoul is now exporting its test kits abroad and holding video conferences with other countries to share its COVID-19 know-how.
Oh Jung-hee, Arirang News.
Reporter : jhlucyoh@arirang.com
contents.headline:
UN chief praises S. Korea's 'remarkable' response to COVID-19 outbreak
Updated: 2020-05-01 17:15:53 KST

contents.context:
Social distancing guidelines crafted by the U.S. federal government to stem the spread of coronavirus expired on Thursday.
President Trump announced on Wednesday that the six-week long restriction will not be extended.
It is now up to each state to decide what to do next based on recommendations from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
With what is likely to be welcome news for the 30 million who have lost their jobs, some U.S. news outlets report at least 28 states will be partially reopened by the end of the week.
But, there is an air of concern over a possible second wave.
Total fatalities in the U.S. have exceeded 63-thousand while over one-million have been infected by COVID-19.
Reporter : kelee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
With expiration of U.S. federal 'Stay-Home' order, at least 28 states to reopen
Updated: 2020-05-01 17:15:37 KST

contents.context:
Unemployment continues to be a serious issue in the U.S, as first time filings for unemployment benefits hit 3.eight-four million last week, bringing the six-week total to over 30 million Americans.
While the pace has slowed since last month, experts say current unemployment claims could be undercounted by as much as 12 million, as those who are eligible for benefits are not getting them due to their inability to file or other roadblocks.
Among the states that have seen the most number of unemployment filings, Washington showed the biggest gains over the past week,.. with more than 62-thousand.
Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com
contents.headline:
First-time filings for U.S. unemployment benefits reaches over 30 million in past six weeks
Updated: 2020-05-01 10:03:35 KST

contents.context:
The total number of COVID-19 cases worldwide has topped 3.2 million, with deaths spiking above 231-thousand.
And another big political name has tested positive.
Russian Prime Minister Mikhail (miss-huzz-tin) Mishustin said Thursday that he has the virus, becoming the highest-ranking Russian official to have contracted COVID-19.
Russia now has over 100-thousand cases, after adding over 7-thousand new cases in a single day.
In the UK, the death toll has jumped to 26-thousand.
The country's Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who recently recovered from COVID-19, returned to the daily briefing on Thursday telling the British people that the country is "past the peak and on the downward slope."
In Asia,. Japan is gearing up to extend its coronavirus emergency for another month, from its original end date of May 6th.
Japan has confirmed around 15-thousand cases, and its death toll is approaching 500.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
COVID-19 gripping the world: Russian PM tests positive for virus
Updated: 2020-05-01 10:03:16 KST
